The patient is a 26-year-old woman with a history of depression, PTSD, and borderline personality disorder who was admitted after ingesting a large overdose of aspirin (ASA). She presented with hypotension and tachycardia, for which she required vasopressor support but has since improved. The patient also had fever initially but has been afebrile since the morning of September 24th. She complained of a headache, nausea, and photophobia, which are symptoms consistent with ASA overdose. However, her bicarbonate level decreased to 7.46 at midnight, and she was given 2 amps of NaHCO3.

The patient developed a brisk bloody pink urine (BRBPR) in the evening, and her hemoglobin concentration (Hct) trended down from 32.3 to 22. Imaging studies, such as a CT scan of the head, showed no evidence of cerebral edema or acute intracranial abnormalities.

The patient has several medical complications, including anemia, acute thrombocytopenia, poisoning/overdose of salicylates, psychiatric disease, and fever of unknown origin.
